article_title: Ending Obamacare's Medicaid Policy Would Be Big Improvement

article_metadata.description: A central problem with Medicaid, which existed before the Affordable Care Act took effect, is that enrollees receive little value from the program. A large body of research also shows that Medicaid enrollees tend to suffer worse outcomes than similar patients without Medicaid. The ACA’s Medicaid expansion exacerbated the program’s perverse incentives with the elevated federal reimbursement of Medicaid spending for the generally working-age, able-bodied adults expansion population. The elevated reimbursement rate further disincentivizes states to care about the value that Medicaid enrollees receive from the program and will undoubtedly lead to large additional spending on behalf of people who obtain little value from it. Moreover, the elevated rate is not equitable as the federal government now provides much greater support for the able-bodied, working-age adult population than for the more vulnerable traditional Medicaid populations.
article_metadata.author: The Apothecary
